biogHist.abstract:
The Adoption of Children Act 1896 first governed legal adoptions in Western Australia, which since 1995 have been subject to the Adoption Act 1994 and Adoption Rules and Regulations 1995. The first adoption was granted by the Supreme Court in 1898 but it was not until 1917 that the Secretary of the State Children Department was required to give permission for a state child to be adopted.
From the 1930s, the government was proactive in encouraging the adoption of children who were state wards, even publishing pictures of 'available' children in the newspaper. Rising numbers of adoptions were proudly reported in the annual reports of the Child Welfare Department.
biogHist.p: By 1937, the Child Welfare Department (CWD) was reporting that there were more children living in institutions than in foster-care. This concerned them, because it was believed that children did not get a sense of the social side of life when they grew up in an institution and that they needed to have contact with adults and children 'leading normal lives in the outside world'. Adoption was seen as a good long-term solution which would also relieve the short-term problem of overcrowding in the institutions. This was coupled with a genuine belief that the best outcome for a young mother and her illegitimate child was a 'fresh start' for both of them through adoption.

In 1926, the original Act had been amended to increase secrecy provisions so that the identity of the child from its birth parents, and vice versa, was hidden by law. The 1994 Act relaxes these secrecy provisions somewhat.
The Western Australian Department for Child Protection and Family Support (2012) describes adoption as follows:

'Adoption is a service that provides a family for a child who is unable, for a range of reasons, to live with their birth parents. It is a permanent legal arrangement (finalised by an Adoption Order from the Family Court of Western Australia, or an overseas Order recognised by the Family Court) that cuts a child's legal ties with their birth family. Full parental rights and responsibilities are given to the adoptive family. This means the birth parents no longer have legal rights over the child, and cannot claim back the child. The child becomes a full member of the adoptive family. This includes taking their surname and assuming the same rights and privileges as if born to them, including the right of inheritance.

Adoptions, including the adoption of children from overseas, are arranged within a highly regulated framework. The Adoption Act 1994 which guides the provision of adoption services in Western Australia is based upon the central principle of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child - that the best interests of the child are paramount. The Act also gives effect to the Hague Convention on the Protection of Children and Cooperation in respect to Intercountry Adoption. In Western Australia, the Department for Child Protection and Family Support, through its Adoption Service, is the only agency allowed to arrange adoptions.

The undesirable consequences of past adoption practices, which were shrouded in secrecy, have led to changes in adoption law both nationally and internationally. West Australian legislation endorses open adoption which recognises a child's birth parentage and cultural origins and promotes contact between the parties to adoption is encouraged where this is possible and appropriate. '

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act 1945

archref.repository: State Law Publisher of Western Australia
archref.unittitle: Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act 1945
archref.abstract: The Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act 1945 extended the secrecy about original birth records to all children adopted in WA (regardless where in Australia they had been born) and to all WA-born people who had been adopted (regardless where in Australia the adoption order was granted).

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Adoption Regulations 1995 (WA)
Happy and Carefree Natures Caught By the Cameraman In These Studies of Young Western Australians

archref.unittitle: Happy and Carefree Natures Caught By the Cameraman In These Studies of Young Western Australians
archref.abstract: This is a picture from the Sunday Times newspaper, which is published on the National Library of Australia's website, 'Trove'. It shows a small boy who is being 'offered' for adoption. He is included with three other children in an article seeking adoptive parents for children who were wards of the state.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Adoption of Children Act 1896

archref.repository: State Law Publisher of Western Australia
archref.abstract: This is a version of the Adoption Act 1896, which is published on the State Law Publisher of Western Australia's website. This Act made it possible to legally adopt children in WA.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Adoption of Children Amendment Act 1976

archref.repository: State Law Publisher of Western Australia
archref.abstract: The Adoption of Children Amendment Act 1976 amended the 1896 Adoption of Children Act to remove the term 'illegitimate child' and clarify 'undue influence'.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act 1964

archref.repository: State Law Publisher of Western Australia
archref.unittitle: Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act 1964
archref.abstract: The Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act 1964 contained a number of amendments designed to 'modernise' the laws relating to adoption in Western Australia and to harmonise adoption laws across Australia.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Adoption of Children Amendment Act 1985

archref.repository: State Law Publisher of Western Australia
archref.abstract: The Adoption of Children Amendment Act 1985 made it possible for 'private adoption agencies' to register and arrange adoptions under the Act.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Adoption Act 1994 (WA)
Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act 1926

archref.repository: State Law Publisher of Western Australia
archref.unittitle: Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act 1926
archref.abstract: The Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act 1926 further increased the secrecy surrounding adoption by enabling a new birth certificate to be issued upon adoption if the adoptive parents applied to do so.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Placed out for adoption in good homes, 1928

archref.repository: Department for Child Protection and Family Support, Annual Report of the Child Welfare Department, 1928, after p.1
archref.unittitle: Placed out for adoption in good homes, 1928
archref.abstract: 'Placed out for adoption in good homes, 1928' is a digital copy of an image included (after p.1) in the Annual Report of the Child Welfare Department, 1928.The caption reads, 'Placed out for adoption in good homes. (Not for reproduction in the Press)'.
archref.note: Department for Child Protection and Family Support

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act, 1971

archref.repository: State Law Publisher of Western Australia
archref.unittitle: Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act, 1971
archref.abstract: The Adoption of Children Amendment Act, 1971 ensured that people who had been adopted as children had equal rights to inherit along with their siblings who had been 'naturally born' into the family. The role of the Director of child welfare in guardianship was also clarified and the criteria for determining suitability to adopt were outlined.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act 1949

archref.repository: State Law Publisher of Western Australia
archref.unittitle: Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act 1949
archref.abstract: The Adoption of Children Amendment Act 1949 made the registration of an adopted child (and therefore a new birth certificate) automatic. Previously, parents who adopted a child had had to apply to the Registrar General for a new birth entry to be made. Also, children over the age of 12 years no longer had to consent to their adoption if the Judge deemed there were 'special circumstances' (such as the child not knowing he or she was not born to the parents who were seeking adoption).

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act 1973

archref.repository: State Law Publisher of Western Australia
archref.unittitle: Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act 1973
archref.abstract: The Adoption of Children Amendment Act, 1973 further protected the interests of people who were adopting children and the identities of all parties involved. The amendments also removed the requirement for the Department for Community Welfare to inspect families who were adopting a step-child.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act (No. 2) 1953

archref.repository: State Law Publisher of Western Australia
archref.unittitle: Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act (No. 2) 1953
archref.abstract: The Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act (No. 2) 1953 enabled a child born outside Australia but adopted in WA to have their adoption registered here as a new birth entry. This had the effect of breaking the link between the child's origins and his or her new identity, as it had for Australian-born children who were adopted after 1945.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Adoption of Children Amendment Act 1980

archref.repository: State Law Publisher of Western Australia
archref.abstract: The Adoption of Children Amendment Act 1980 enabled children over the age of 12 years to retain their original surname if the Judge deemed this to be in their best interests. The amendments also gave the Director responsible for child welfare the ability to supervise children adopted internationally for the first 12 months after their arrival in Australia.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Matron and sisters at the Salvation Army Hillcrest maternity home, North Fremantle, with some new arrivals

archref.unittitle: Matron and sisters at the Salvation Army Hillcrest maternity home, North Fremantle, with some new arrivals
archref.abstract: This photograph is from an article in the Western Mail which is held on the National Library's website, 'Trove'. It shows some of the newborn babies at Hillcrest, the Salvation Army's maternity hospital in North Fremantle. Many of the babies born to 'unmarried mothers' at Hillcrest were adopted.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act 1921

archref.repository: State Law Publisher of Western Australia
archref.unittitle: Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act 1921
archref.abstract: This is a version of the Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act 1921, which is published on the State Law Publisher of Western Australia's website. This Act made the adopted child's birth surname secret.
